cleaned_text: is a [pseudoscientific](/wiki/Pseudoscientific) [[1]](#cite_note-1) system of [alternative medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine). It was conceived in 1796 by the German physician [Samuel Hahnemann](/wiki/Samuel_Hahnemann). Its practitioners, called homeopaths, believe that a substance that causes symptoms of a disease in healthy people can cure similar symptoms in sick people; this doctrine is called [similia similibus curentur](/wiki/Similia_similibus_curentur), or "like cures like". [[2]](#cite_note-Hahnemann-2) Homeopathic termed remedies and are made using [homeopathic dilution](/wiki/Homeopathic_dilution). In this process, the selected substance is repeatedly diluted until the final product is chemically indistinguishable from the [diluent](/wiki/Diluent). Often not even a single molecule of the original substance can be expected to remain in the product. [[3]](#cite_note-3) Between each dilution homeopaths may hit and/or shake the product, claiming this makes the diluent remember the original substance after its removal. Practitioners claim that such preparations, upon oral intake, can treat or cure disease. [[4]](#cite_note-4) All relevant scientific knowledge about physics, chemistry, biochemistry and biology contradicts homeopathy. [[5]](#cite_note-5) Homeopathic remedies are typically [biochemically](/wiki/Biochemistry) inert, and have no effect on any known disease. [[6]](#cite_note-shang-6) [[7]](#cite_note-pmid124926032-7) [[8]](#cite_note-inquiry_4504-8) Its theory of disease, centered around principles Hahnemann termed [miasms](#Miasms_and_disease), is inconsistent with subsequent identification of viruses and bacteria as [causes of disease](/wiki/Germ_theory_of_disease). Clinical trials have been conducted and generally demonstrated no objective effect from homeopathic preparations. [[9]](#cite_note-Caulfield20053-9) [[10]](#cite_note-sbm-fun-10) [[11]](#cite_note-Shelton-11): 206 [[12]](#cite_note-Ernst20102-12) The fundamental implausibility of homeopathy as well as a lack of demonstrable effectiveness has led to it being characterized within the scientific and medical communities as [quackery](/wiki/Quackery) and [fraud](/wiki/Fraud). [[13]](#cite_note-Baran2014-13) [[14]](#cite_note-Walport-Nonsense-14) [[15]](#cite_note-oxcompus-15) Homeopathy achieved its greatest popularity in the 19th century. It was introduced to the United States in 1825, and the first American homeopathic school opened in 1835. Throughout the 19th century, dozens of homeopathic institutions appeared in Europe and the United States. During this period, homeopathy was able to appear relatively successful, as other forms of treatment could be harmful and ineffective. By the end of the century the practice began to wane, with the last exclusively homeopathic medical school in the United States closing in 1920. During the 1970s, homeopathy made a significant comeback, with sales of some homeopathic products increasing tenfold. The trend corresponded with the rise of the [New Age movement](/wiki/New_Age_movement), and may be in part due to [chemophobia](/wiki/Chemophobia), an irrational aversion to synthetic chemicals, and the longer consultation times homeopathic practitioners provided. In the 21st century, a series of [meta-analyses](/wiki/Meta-analysis) have shown that the therapeutic claims of homeopathy lack scientific justification. As a result, national and international bodies have recommended the withdrawal of government funding for homeopathy in healthcare. National bodies from Australia, the United Kingdom, Switzerland and France, as well as the [European Academies' Science Advisory Council](/wiki/European_Academies%27_Science_Advisory_Council) and the [Russian Academy of Sciences](/wiki/Russian_Academy_of_Sciences) have all concluded that homeopathy is ineffective, and recommended against the practice receiving any further funding. [[16]](#cite_note-Conversation-NHMRC-16) [[17]](#cite_note-17) [[18]](#cite_note-18) [[19]](#cite_note-19) The [National Health Service in England](/wiki/NHS_England) no longer provides funding for homeopathic remedies and asked the [Department of Health](/wiki/Department_of_Health_and_Social_Care) to add homeopathic remedies to the list of forbidden prescription items. [[20]](#cite_note-20) [[21]](#cite_note-TNHS-21) [[22]](#cite_note-bbc-blacklist-22) France removed funding in 2021, [[23]](#cite_note-GuardianFrance-23) [[24]](#cite_note-FranceEndFunding2021-24) while Spain has also announced moves to ban homeopathy and other pseudotherapies from health centers. [[25]](#cite_note-El_Pais_2019-07-30-25) History Homeopathy, the longest established [alternative medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine) to come out of Europe, was created in 1796 by [Samuel Hahnemann](/wiki/Samuel_Hahnemann). [[26]](#cite_note-26) Hahnemann rejected the mainstream medicine of the late 18th century as irrational and inadvisable because it was largely ineffective and often harmful. [[27]](#cite_note-Lasagna-27) [[28]](#cite_note-isbn0-393-06661-4-28) He advocated the use of single drugs at lower doses and promoted an immaterial, [vitalistic](/wiki/Vitalism) view of how living organisms function. [[29]](#cite_note-Pray2003-29) The term homeopathy was coined by Hahnemann and first appeared in print in 1807. [[30]](#cite_note-30) He also coined the expression " [allopathic medicine](/wiki/Allopathic_medicine)", which was used to pejoratively refer to traditional Western medicine. [[31]](#cite_note-Whorton2004-31) Concept Hahnemann conceived of homeopathy while translating a medical treatise by the Scottish physician and chemist [William Cullen](/wiki/William_Cullen) into German. Being sceptical of Cullen's theory that [cinchona](/wiki/Cinchona) cured [malaria](/wiki/Malaria) because it was bitter, Hahnemann ingested some bark specifically to investigate what would happen. He experienced fever, shivering and [joint pain](/wiki/Arthralgia): symptoms similar to those of malaria itself. From this, Hahnemann came to believe that all effective drugs produce symptoms in healthy individuals similar to those of the diseases that they treat. [[32]](#cite_note-UllmanReichenberg-Ullman1994-32) This led to the name "homeopathy", which comes from the [Greek](/wiki/Greek_language): hómoios, "-like" and páthos, "suffering". [[33]](#cite_note-33) The doctrine that those drugs are effective which produce symptoms similar to the symptoms caused by the diseases they treat, called "the law of similars", was expressed by Hahnemann with the does not derive from the [scientific method](/wiki/Scientific_method). [[34]](#cite_note-Kirk-34) An account of the effects of eating cinchona bark noted by [Oliver Wendell Holmes](/wiki/Oliver_Wendell_Holmes,_Sr.), published in 1861, failed to reproduce the symptoms Hahnemann reported. [[35]](#cite_note-Holmes-35): 128 Subsequent scientific work showed that cinchona cures malaria because it contains [quinine](/wiki/Quinine), which kills the [Plasmodium falciparum](/wiki/Plasmodium_falciparum) parasite that causes the disease; the mechanism of action is unrelated to Hahnemann's ideas. [[36]](#cite_note-Atwood-BTTF1-36) Provings Hahnemann began to test what effects various substances may produce in humans, a procedure later called "homeopathic proving". These tests required subjects to test the effects of ingesting substances by recording all their symptoms as well as the ancillary conditions under which they appeared. [[37]](#cite_note-Haehl1922-37) He published a collection of provings in 1805, and a second collection of 65 preparations appeared in his book, Materia Medica Pura (1810). [[38]](#cite_note-Kirschmann2004-38) As Hahnemann believed that large doses of drugs that caused similar symptoms would only aggravate illness, he advocated for extreme dilutions. A technique was devised for making dilutions that Hahnemann claimed would preserve the substance's therapeutic properties while removing its harmful effects. [[39]](#cite_note-Dynamization_and_Dilution-39) Hahnemann believed that this process enhanced "the spirit-like medicinal powers of the crude substances". [[40]](#cite_note-Organon_5th_269-40) He gathered and published an overview of his new medical system in his book, [The Organon of the Healing Art](/wiki/The_Organon_of_the_Healing_Art) (1810), with a sixth edition published in 1921 that homeopaths still use today. [[41]](#cite_note-homhist1-41) Miasms and disease In the Organon, Hahnemann introduced the concept of "miasms" as the "infectious underlying chronic disease vital force". [[43]](#cite_note-Grimes2012-43) Hahnemann associated each miasm with specific diseases, and thought that initial exposure to miasms causes local symptoms, such as skin or venereal diseases. His assertion was that if these symptoms were suppressed by medication, the cause went deeper and began to manifest itself as diseases of the internal organs. [[44]](#cite_note-miasms-44) Homeopathy maintains that treating diseases by directly [alleviating their symptoms](/wiki/Symptomatic_treatment), as is sometimes done in conventional medicine, is ineffective because all "disease can generally be traced to some latent, deep-seated, underlying chronic, or inherited tendency". [[45]](#cite_note-45) The underlying imputed miasm still remains, and deep-seated ailments can be corrected only by removing the deeper disturbance of the vital force. [[46]](#cite_note-homphilo-46) Hahnemann's [hypotheses](/wiki/Hypotheses) for miasms originally presented only three local psora (the itch), syphilis (venereal disease) or sycosis (fig-wart disease). [[47]](#cite_note-47) Of these the most important was psora, described as being related to any itching diseases of the skin and was claimed to be the foundation of many further disease conditions. Hahnemann believed it to be the cause of such diseases as [epilepsy](/wiki/Epilepsy), [cancer](/wiki/Cancer), [jaundice](/wiki/Jaundice), [deafness](/wiki/Deafness), and [cataracts](/wiki/Cataracts). [[48]](#cite_note-Hahnemann_Chronic-48) Since Hahnemann's time, other miasms have been proposed, some replacing illnesses previously attributed to the psora, including [tuberculosis](/wiki/Tuberculosis) and [cancer](/wiki/Cancer) miasms. [[44]](#cite_note-miasms-44) Hahnemann's miasm theory remains disputed and controversial within homeopathy even in modern times. The theory of miasms has been criticized as an explanation developed to preserve the system of homeopathy in the face of treatment failures, and for being inadequate to cover the many hundreds of sorts of diseases, as well as for failing to explain disease predispositions, as well as [genetics](/wiki/Genetics), environmental factors, and the unique disease history of each patient. [[11]](#cite_note-Shelton-11): 148-9 19th century: rise to popularity and early criticism Homeopathy achieved its greatest popularity in the 19th century. It was introduced to the United States in 1825 by Hans Birch Gram, a student of Hahnemann. [[49]](#cite_note-Miller-49) The first homeopathic school in the United States opened in 1835 and the [American Institute of Homeopathy](/wiki/American_Institute_of_Homeopathy) was established in 1844. Throughout the 19th century, dozens of homeopathic institutions appeared in Europe and the United States, [[50]](#cite_note-Julian-50) and by 1900, there were 22 homeopathic colleges and 15,000 practitioners in the United States. [[51]](#cite_note-Time19951125-51) Because medical practice of the time relied on treatments which were often ineffective and harmful, patients of homeopaths often had better outcomes than those being treated by medical practitioners. [[52]](#cite_note-pmid8885813-52) Though ineffective, homeopathic preparations are rarely detrimental, thus users are less likely to be harmed by the treatment that is supposed to be helping them. [[41]](#cite_note-homhist1-41) The relative success of homeopathy in the 19th century may have led to the abandonment of the ineffective and harmful treatments of [bloodletting](/wiki/Bloodletting) and purging and begun the move towards more effective, [science-based medicine](/wiki/Science-based_medicine). [[53]](#cite_note-kaufmanm-53) One reason for the growing popularity of homeopathy was its apparent success in treating people suffering from infectious disease epidemics. [[54]](#cite_note-54) During 19th-century epidemics of diseases such as [cholera](/wiki/Cholera), death rates in homeopathic hospitals were often lower than in conventional hospitals, where the treatments used at the time were often harmful and did little or nothing to combat the diseases. [[55]](#cite_note-55) Even during its rise in popularity, homeopathy was criticized by scientists and physicians. [Sir John Forbes](/wiki/John_Forbes_(physician)), physician to [Queen Victoria](/wiki/Victoria_of_the_United_Kingdom), said in 1843 that the extremely small doses of homeopathy were regularly derided as useless and considered it "an outrage to human reason". [[56]](#cite_note-John_Forbes-56) [James Young Simpson](/wiki/James_Young_Simpson) said in 1853 of the highly diluted drugs: "No poison, however strong or powerful, the billionth or decillionth of which would in the least degree affect a man or harm a fly." [[57]](#cite_note-57) Nineteenth-century American physician and author [Oliver Wendell Holmes](/wiki/Oliver_Wendell_Holmes_Sr.) was also a vocal critic of homeopathy and published an essay entitled [Homopathy and Its Kindred Delusions](/wiki/Hom%C5%93opathy_and_Its_Kindred_Delusions) (1842). [[35]](#cite_note-Holmes-35) The members of the French Homeopathic Society observed in 1867 that some leading homeopaths of Europe not only were abandoning the practice of administering infinitesimal doses but were also no longer defending it. [[58]](#cite_note-58) The last school in the United States exclusively teaching homeopathy closed in 1920. [[41]](#cite_note-homhist1-41) Revival in the 20th century According to academics [Paul U. Unschuld](/w/index.php?title=Paul_U._Unschuld&action=edit&redlink=1) and [Edzard Ernst](/wiki/Edzard_Ernst), the [Nazi](/wiki/Nazi) regime in Germany was fond of homeopathy, and spent large sums of money on researching its mechanisms, but without gaining a positive result. [[59]](#cite_note-59) Unschuld also states that homeopathy never subsequently took root in the [United States](/wiki/United_States), but remained more deeply established in European thinking. [[60]](#cite_note-Unschuld2009-60) In the United States, the [Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act](/wiki/Federal_Food,_Drug,_and_Cosmetic_Act) of 1938 (sponsored by [Royal Copeland](/wiki/Royal_S._Copeland), a [Senator](/wiki/United_States_Senate) from [New York](/wiki/New_York_(state)) and homeopathic physician) recognized homeopathic preparations as drugs. In the 1950s, there were only 75 solely homeopathic practitioners in the U.S. [[61]](#cite_note-61) By the mid to late 1970s, homeopathy made a significant comeback and the sales of some homeopathic companies increased tenfold. [[62]](#cite_note-rader-62) Some homeopaths credit the revival to Greek homeopath [George Vithoulkas](/wiki/George_Vithoulkas), who conducted a "great deal of research to update the scenarios and refine the theories and practice of homeopathy" in the 1970s, [[63]](#cite_note-pmid12614092-63) [[64]](#cite_note-64) but Ernst and [Simon Singh](/wiki/Simon_Singh) consider it to be linked to the rise of the [New Age movement](/wiki/New_Age_movement). [[28]](#cite_note-isbn0-393-06661-4-28) [Bruce Hood](/wiki/Bruce_Hood_(psychologist)) has argued that the increased popularity of homeopathy in recent times may be due to the comparatively long consultations practitioners are willing to give their patients, and to a [preference for "natural" products](/wiki/Appeal_to_nature), which people think are the basis of homeopathic preparations. [[65]](#cite_note-Hood2009-65) Towards the end of the century opposition to homeopathy began to increase again; with [William T. Jarvis](/wiki/William_T._Jarvis), the President of the [National Council Against Health Fraud](/wiki/National_Council_Against_Health_Fraud), saying that "Homeopathy is a fraud perpetrated on the public with the government's blessing, thanks to the abuse of political power of Sen. Royal S. Copeland." [[66]](#cite_note-66) 21st century: renewed criticism Since the beginning of the 21st century, a series of [meta-analyses](/wiki/Meta-analysis) have further shown that the therapeutic claims of homeopathy lack scientific justification. [[67]](#cite_note-champe-67) This had led to a decrease or suspension of funding by many governments. In a 2010 report, the [Science and Technology Committee of the United Kingdom House of Commons](/wiki/Science_and_Technology_Select_Committee) recommended that homeopathy should no longer receive [National Health Service](/wiki/National_Health_Service) (NHS) funding due its lack of scientific credibility; [[67]](#cite_note-champe-67) NHS funding for homeopathy ceased in 2017. [[21]](#cite_note-TNHS-21) They also asked the [Department of Health](/wiki/Department_of_Health_and_Social_Care) in the UK to add homeopathic remedies to the list of forbidden prescription items. [[22]](#cite_note-bbc-blacklist-22) In 2015, the [National Health and Medical Research Council](/wiki/National_Health_and_Medical_Research_Council) of Australia found that "there are no health conditions for which there is reliable evidence that homeopathy is effective". [[68]](#cite_note-68) The federal government only ended up accepting three of the 45 recommendations made by the 2018 review of Pharmacy Remuneration and Regulation. [[69]](#cite_note-69) The same year the US [Food and Drug Administration](/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration) (FDA) held a hearing requesting public comment on the regulation of homeopathic drugs. [[70]](#cite_note-Science42115-70) In 2017 the FDA announced it would strengthen regulation of homeopathic products. [[71]](#cite_note-Frazier_FDA_to_Reg-71) The American non-profit [Center for Inquiry](/wiki/Center_for_Inquiry) (CFI) filed a lawsuit in 2018 against the [CVS](/wiki/CVS_Pharmacy) pharmacy for consumer fraud over its sale of homeopathic medicines. [[72]](#cite_note-CVS-72) It claimed that CVS was selling homeopathic products on an easier-to-obtain basis than standard medication. [[73]](#cite_note-73) In 2019, CFI brought a similar lawsuit against [Walmart](/wiki/Walmart) for "committing wide-scale consumer fraud and endangering the health of its customers through its sale and marketing of homeopathic medicines". [[74]](#cite_note-74) [[75]](#cite_note-75) They also conducted a survey in which they found consumers felt ripped off when informed of the lack of evidence for the efficacy of homeopathic remedies, such as those sold by Walmart and CVS. [[76]](#cite_note-CFISurvey_SI_2019-76) [[77]](#cite_note-CFI_2019_Survey-77) In 2021, the French healthcare minister phased out social security reimbursements for homeopathic drugs. [[23]](#cite_note-GuardianFrance-23) [[24]](#cite_note-FranceEndFunding2021-24) France has long had a stronger belief in the virtues of homeopathic drugs than many other countries and the world's biggest manufacturer of alternative medicine drugs, [Boiron](/wiki/Boiron), is located in that country. [[78]](#cite_note-78) Spain has also announced moves to ban homeopathy and other pseudotherapies. [[25]](#cite_note-El_Pais_2019-07-30-25) In 2016, the [University of Barcelona](/wiki/University_of_Barcelona) cancelled its master's degree in Homeopathy citing "lack of scientific basis", after advice from the Spanish Ministry of Health. [[79]](#cite_note-79) Shortly afterwards the [University of Valencia](/wiki/University_of_Valencia) announced the elimination of its Masters in Homeopathy. [[80]](#cite_note-80) Preparations and treatment Homeopathic preparations are referred to as "homeopathic remedies". [[81]](#cite_note-Consumer_Reports-81) Practitioners rely on two types of [Materia medica](/wiki/Materia_medica) and repertories. "drug pictures", organized alphabetically. A homeopathic repertory is a quick reference version of the materia medica that indexes the symptoms and then the associated remedies for each. In both cases different compilers may dispute particular inclusions in the references. [[82]](#cite_note-82) The first symptomatic homeopathic materia medica was arranged The first homeopathic was Georg Jahr's Symptomenkodex, published in German in 1835, and translated into English as the Repertory to the more Characteristic Symptoms of Materia Medica in 1838. This version was less focused on disease categories and was the forerunner to later works by [James Tyler Kent](/wiki/James_Tyler_Kent). [[83]](#cite_note-pmid16322800-83) [[84]](#cite_note-84) There are over 118 repertories published in English, with Kent's being one of the most used. [[85]](#cite_note-85) Consultation Homeopaths generally begin with a consultation, which can be a 10-15 minute appointment or last for over an hour, where the patient describes their [medical history](/wiki/Medical_history). The patient describes the "modalities", or if their symptoms change depending on the weather and other external factors. [[86]](#cite_note-Vickers_1115-11182-86) The practitioner also solicits information on mood, likes and dislikes, physical, mental and emotional states, life circumstances, and any physical or emotional illnesses. [[87]](#cite_note-Stehlin-87) This information (also called the "symptom picture") is matched to the "drug picture" in the materia medica or repertory and used to determine the appropriate homeopathic remedies. In classical homeopathy, the practitioner attempts to match a single preparation to the totality of symptoms (the simlilum), while "clinical homeopathy" involves combinations of preparations based on the illness's symptoms. [[63]](#cite_note-pmid12614092-63) Preparation Homeopathy uses animal, plant, mineral, and synthetic substances in its preparations, generally referring to them using [Latin](/wiki/Latin) names. [[88]](#cite_note-WHO_Safety-88) is to ensure accuracy. [[89]](#cite_note-89) In the USA the common name must be displayed, although the Latin one can also be present. [[88]](#cite_note-WHO_Safety-88) Homeopathic pills are made from an inert substance (often sugars, typically lactose), upon which a drop of liquid homeopathic preparation is placed and allowed to evaporate. [[90]](#cite_note-Ernst2005-90) [[91]](#cite_note-91) Isopathy is a therapy derived from homeopathy in which the preparations come from diseased or pathological products such as fecal, urinary and respiratory discharges, blood, and tissue. [[83]](#cite_note-pmid16322800-83) They are called nosodes (from the Greek nosos, disease) with preparations made from "healthy" specimens being termed "sarcodes". Many so-called "homeopathic vaccines" are a form of isopathy. [[92]](#cite_note-92) Tautopathy is a form of isopathy where the preparations are composed of drugs or vaccines that a person has consumed in the past, in the belief that this can reverse the supposed lingering damage caused by the initial use. [[93]](#cite_note-93) There is no convincing scientific evidence for isopathy as an effective method of treatment. [[94]](#cite_note-94) Some modern homeopaths use preparations they call "imponderables" because they do not originate from a substance but some other phenomenon presumed to have been "captured" by alcohol or [lactose](/wiki/Lactose). Examples include [X-rays](/wiki/X-ray) [[95]](#cite_note-95) and [sunlight](/wiki/Sunlight). [[96]](#cite_note-96) Another derivative is [electrohomeopathy](/wiki/Electrohomeopathy), where an electric bio-energy of therapeutic value is supposedly extracted from plants. Popular in the late nineteenth century, electrohomeopathy is extremely pseudo-scientific. [[97]](#cite_note-97) In 2012, the Allahabad High Court in Uttar Pradesh, India, handed down a decree stating that electrohomeopathy was quackery and no longer recognized it as a system of medicine . [[98]](#cite_note-toie-98) Other minority practices include paper preparations, in which the terms for substances and dilutions are written on pieces of paper and either pinned to the patients' clothing, put in their pockets, or placed under glasses of water that are then given to the patients. [Radionics](/wiki/Radionics), the use of [electromagnetic radiation](/wiki/Electromagnetic_radiation) such as [radio waves](/wiki/Radio_wave), can also be used to manufacture preparations. Such practices have been strongly criticized by classical homeopaths as unfounded, speculative, and verging upon magic and superstition. [[99]](#cite_note-99) [[100]](#cite_note-Barwell-100) Flower preparations are produced by placing flowers in water and exposing them to sunlight. The most famous of these are the [Bach flower remedies](/wiki/Bach_flower_remedies), which were developed by [Edward Bach](/wiki/Edward_Bach). [[101]](#cite_note-101) Dilutions Hahnemann claimed that undiluted doses caused reactions, sometimes dangerous ones, and thus that preparations be given at the lowest possible dose. [[102]](#cite_note-Kayne_53-102) A solution that is more dilute is described as having a higher "potency", and thus are claimed to be stronger and deeper-acting. [[103]](#cite_note-103) The general method of dilution is [serial dilution](/wiki/Serial_dilution), where solvent is added to part of the previous mixture, but the "Korsakovian" method may also be used. In the Korsakovian method, the vessel in which the preparations are manufactured is emptied, refilled with solvent, with the volume of fluid adhering to the walls of the vessel deemed sufficient for the new batch. [[11]](#cite_note-Shelton-11): 270 The Korsakovian method is sometimes referred to as K on the label of a homeopathic preparation. [[104]](#cite_note-104) [[105]](#cite_note-105) Another method is Fluxion, which dilutes the substance by continuously passing water through the vial. [[106]](#cite_note-106) Insoluble solids, such as [granite](/wiki/Granite), [diamond](/wiki/Diamond), and [platinum](/wiki/Platinum), are diluted by grinding them with lactose (" [trituration](/wiki/Trituration)"). [[11]](#cite_note-Shelton-11): 23 Three main [logarithmic](/wiki/Logarithmic_scale) dilution scales are in regular use in homeopathy. Hahnemann created the "centesimal" or "C scale", diluting a substance by a factor of 100 at each stage. There is also a decimal dilution scale (notated as "X" or "D") in which the preparation is diluted by a factor of 10 at each stage. [[107]](#cite_note-107) The centesimal scale was favoured by Hahnemann for most of his life, although in his last ten years Hahnemann developed a quintamillesimal (Q) scale which diluted the drug 1 part in 50,000. [[108]](#cite_note-108) A 2C dilution works out to one part of the original substance in 10,000 parts of the solution. In standard chemistry, this produces a substance with a concentration of 0.01% ( [volume-volume percentage](/wiki/Concentration#Volume-volume_percentage)). A 6C dilution ends up with the original substance diluted by a factor of 1006 (one part in one trillion). The end product is usually so diluted as to be indistinguishable from the diluent (pure water, sugar or alcohol). [[39]](#cite_note-Dynamization_and_Dilution-39) [[109]](#cite_note-homsim-109) The greatest dilution reasonably likely to contain at least one molecule of the original substance is approximately 12C. [[110]](#cite_note-110) Hahnemann advocated dilutions of 1 [[111]](#cite_note-Organon_6th_128-111) Hahnemann regularly used dilutions of up to 30C but opined that "there must be a limit to the matter". [[37]](#cite_note-Haehl1922-37): 322 To counter the reduced potency at high dilutions he formed the view that vigorous shaking by striking on an elastic surface - a process termed succussion - was necessary. [[102]](#cite_note-Kayne_53-102) Homeopaths are unable to agree on the number and force of strikes needed, and there is no way that the claimed results of succussion can be tested. [[11]](#cite_note-Shelton-11): 67-69 Critics of homeopathy commonly emphasize the dilutions involved in homeopathy, using analogies. [[112]](#cite_note-Appendix2-112) One mathematically correct example is that a 12C solution is equivalent to "a pinch of salt in both the North and South Atlantic Oceans". [[113]](#cite_note-Bambridge-113) [[114]](#cite_note-Andrews-114) [[115]](#cite_note-115) One-third of a [drop](/wiki/Drop_(volume)) of some original substance diluted into all the water on earth would produce a preparation with a concentration of about 13C. [[112]](#cite_note-Appendix2-112) [[116]](#cite_note-116) [[117]](#cite_note-117) A 200C dilution of duck under the name [Oscillococcinum](/wiki/Oscillococcinum), would require 10320 universes worth of molecules to contain just one original molecule in the final substance. [[118]](#cite_note-118) The high dilutions characteristically used are often considered to be the most controversial and implausible aspect of homeopathy. [[119]](#cite_note-119) Provings Homeopaths claim that they can determine the properties of their preparations by following a method which they call "proving". [[120]](#cite_note-120) As performed by Hahnemann, provings involved administering various preparations to healthy volunteers. The volunteers were then observed, often for months at a time. They were made to keep extensive journals detailing all of their symptoms at specific times throughout the day. They were forbidden from consuming coffee, tea, spices, or wine for the duration of the experiment; playing chess was also prohibited because Hahnemann considered it to be "too exciting", though they were allowed to drink beer and encouraged to exercise in moderation. [[121]](#cite_note-121) At first Hahnemann used undiluted doses for provings, but he later advocated provings with preparations at a 30C dilution, [[111]](#cite_note-Organon_6th_128-111) and most modern provings are carried out using ultra-dilute preparations. [[122]](#cite_note-122) Provings are claimed to have been important in the development of the [clinical trial](/wiki/Clinical_trial), due to their early use of simple control groups, systematic and quantitative procedures, and some of the first application of [statistics](/wiki/Statistics) in medicine. [[123]](#cite_note-123) The lengthy records of [self-experimentation](/wiki/Self-experimentation) by homeopaths have occasionally proven useful in the development of modern drugs: For example, evidence that [nitroglycerin](/wiki/Nitroglycerin) might be useful as a treatment for [angina](/wiki/Angina_pectoris) was discovered by looking through homeopathic provings, though homeopaths themselves never used it for that purpose at that time. [[124]](#cite_note-pmid2866851-124) The first recorded provings were published by Hahnemann in his 1796 Essay on a New Principle. [[88]](#cite_note-WHO_Safety-88) [Ontario](/wiki/Ontario) became the first province in the country to regulate the practice of homeopathy, a move that was widely criticized by scientists and doctors. [[270]](#cite_note-270) [Health Canada](/wiki/Health_Canada) requires all products to have a licence before being sold and applicants have to submit evidence on "the safety, efficacy and quality of a homeopathic medicine". [[271]](#cite_note-271) In 2015 the [Canadian Broadcasting Corporation](/wiki/Canadian_Broadcasting_Corporation) tested the system by applying for and then receiving a government approved licence for a made-up drug aimed at kids. [[272]](#cite_note-272) In Australia, the sale of homeopathic products is regulated by the [Therapeutic Goods Administration](/wiki/Therapeutic_Goods_Administration). [[273]](#cite_note-273) In 2015, the [National Health and Medical Research Council](/wiki/National_Health_and_Medical_Research_Council) of Australia concluded that there is "no reliable evidence that homeopathy is effective and should not be used to treat health conditions that are chronic, serious, or could become serious". [[160]](#cite_note-NHMRC2-160) A 2017 review into Pharmacy Remuneration and Regulation recommended that products be banned from pharmacies; [[274]](#cite_note-274) while noting the concerns the government did not adopt the recommendation. [[278]](#cite_note-278) Prevalence Homeopathy is one of the most commonly used forms of alternative medicines and it has a large worldwide market. [[88]](#cite_note-WHO_Safety-88) The exact size is uncertain, but information available on homeopathic sales suggests it forms a large share of the medical market. [[88]](#cite_note-WHO_Safety-88) In 1999, about 1000 UK doctors practiced homeopathy, most being general practitioners who prescribe a limited number of remedies. A further 1500 homeopaths with no medical training are also thought to practice. Over ten thousand German and French doctors use homeopathy. [[86]](#cite_note-Vickers_1115-11182-86) In the United States a National Health Interview Survey estimated 5 million adults and 1 million children used homeopathy in 2011. An analysis of this survey concluded that most cases were self-prescribed for colds and musculoskeletal pain. [[279]](#cite_note-279) Major retailers like [Walmart](/wiki/Walmart), [CVS](/wiki/CVS_Pharmacy), and [Walgreens](/wiki/Walgreens) sell homeopathic products that are packaged to resemble conventional medicines. [[240]](#cite_note-Undark_2020-09-02-240) The homeopathic drug market in Germany is worth about 650 million euro with a 2014 survey finding that 60 percent of Germans reported trying homeopathy. [[240]](#cite_note-Undark_2020-09-02-240) A 2009 survey found that only 17 percent of respondents knew how homeopathic medicine was made. [[240]](#cite_note-Undark_2020-09-02-240) France spent more than US$408 million on homeopathic products in 2008. [[88]](#cite_note-WHO_Safety-88) In the United States the homeopathic market is worth about $3 billion-a-year; [[280]](#cite_note-280) with 2.9 billion spent in 2007. [[88]](#cite_note-WHO_Safety-88) Australia spent US$7.3 million on homeopathic medicines in 2008. [[88]](#cite_note-WHO_Safety-88) In India, a 2014 national health survey found that homeopathy was used by about 3% of the population. [[281]](#cite_note-281) Homeopathy is used in China, although it arrived a lot later than in many other countries, partly due to the restriction on foreigners that persisted until late in the nineteenth century. [[234]](#cite_note-Who_Legal-234) Veterinary use Using homeopathy as a treatment for animals is termed "veterinary homeopathy" and dates back to the inception of homeopathy; Hahnemann himself wrote and spoke of the use of homeopathy in animals other than humans. [[283]](#cite_note-Saxton2007-283) The use of homeopathy in the [organic farming](/wiki/Organic_farming) industry is heavily promoted. [[284]](#cite_note-284) Given that homeopathy's effects in humans are due to the placebo effect and the counseling aspects of the consultation, such treatments are even less effective in animals. [[286]](#cite_note-Hektoen-286) This means that animals given homeopathic remedies will continue to suffer, resulting in [animal welfare](/wiki/Animal_welfare) concerns.
